awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Artificial Intelligence (AI)-enabled point-of-care diagnostic ultrasound for injured children
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-enabled, ultrasound diagnostic technology to safely diagnose internal bleeding in injured children. The current standard of care is to use a computerized tomography (CT) scan to diagnose internal bleeding, however, 4,000 of these children will develop cancer directly caused by the ionizing radiation each year. In addition, from the time the emergency provider orders the CT scan to the radiologist’s final report may be up to 24 hours. The proposed AI-guided ultrasound diagnostic technology may be able to diagnose internal bleeding in childrenwithout cancer-causing radiation and within minutes of arrival. The proposed technology also may give access to expert-level emergency care to those who do not live near a trauma center.  Currently, 30 million people in the US do not live within an hour of a trauma center, and do not have access to CT. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-enabled software to use with existing ultrasound technology to safely diagnose internal bleeding in injured children. The proposed software may guide the acquisition of the correct images of the focused assessment with sonography during the trauma exam and may help interpret the results by identifying free fluid, indicating internal bleeding. A view classification model has been developed that accurately identifies the correct images for the pediatric trauma exam (accuracy of ~98%), and a novel machine learning algorithm to detect internal bleeding is currently in development. These models will be integrated into a software platform that may guide the ultrasound image acquisition, assist in the diagnosis of internal bleeding, and automate documentation workflow.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, SAN FRANCISCO, THE

por.por_cntn:
The NSF I-Corps program seeks to gain insight into product-market fit through customer discovery work. Our team interviewed over 100 clinicians, IT technologists, hospital administrators, industry representatives, and more through the program. We learned that the barriers to point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) in the emergency department (ED) relate to expert-level image acquisition, confidence in interpretation, and overall workflow ease of use.

Training in POCUS is not consistent or sufficient for most clinicians. Many clinicians feel underprepared to acquire the images necessary to evaluate common conditions. Many challenging image views, such as landmark detection for deep venous thrombosis, are challenging. However, even those categorized as simpler POCUS studies were also challenging for many clinicians. The repercussion of these challenging acquisition and inconsistency in training are the lack of use of this fast, safe and effective diagnostic tool.

Underperformance and lack of training also lead to a lack of confidence in acting on POCUS findings. Clinicians shared that even if they thought a study was negative, they may not act on their interpretations. Instead, clinicians rely on radiology-performed studies or other further testing. This is unfortunate because clinicians also believed POCUS alone would save time, resources, and effort, thus improving patient care, overall ED flow, and healthcare costs.

As for workflow, there are many obstacles to performing studies, with barriers related to systems-level lags and workflow prone to error. These include phantom scanning, where images are not saved and documented, long loading times of the order to the POCUS machine, and lack of procedure notes with interpretation. Currently, software and workflow solutions are often inadequate, and therefore, some clinicians don't document or use POCUS and instead become frustrated with the use of POCUS. Clinicians seek solutions that address workflow barriers, including image storage and archive, procedure note documentation, and enhanced quality assurance review.

To address these confidence and workflow barriers to POCUS, we built a clickable wireframe prototype of a web-app-based technology that can optimize the clinician to capture the correct POCUS images, ensure the study is complete, and document their findings. We envisioned this app to be used on a smart device at the bedside where the POCUS study is performed. We also envisioned a wireless bridge and integration with the electronic health record to upload images and documentation to the patient encounter. The clickable prototype allowed users to click through the screens of four different POCUS scenarios. We tested the prototype with multiple potential customers and iterated the design based on stakeholder feedback to make it more usable and valuable for our target customers.

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2024
Modified by: Aaron E Kornblith
